results.title: Yang and yin: gender in Chinese cinema: a film to celebrate 100 years of cinema: by Stanley Kwan
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kwan, British Film Institute, Creation Workshop and Media Asia Distribution
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Yan and Yin: gender in Chinese Cinema is a fascinating insight into Chinese films. In this context ‘Chinese’ incorporates films from Hong Kong and Tawain as well as mainland China. Kwan’s documentary is a highly personal view which looks in particular at subtextual issues of homosexuality and transexuality in Chinese films. The film includes interviews with John Woo, Ang Lee, Hou Hsiao Hsien, Leslie Cheung, Chen Kaige and Chang Cheh, who was an integral director in the Shaw Brothers martial arts films from which Bruce Lee emerged. There are also countless excerpts from films which span the century, including early Chinese cinema and Cantonese Opera Films featuring Yan Kin-Fai and Baak Suet-Sin, a famous lesbian couple who were extremely popular in the fifties. There are also excerpts from “Way of the Dragon” (Bruce Lee), John Woo’s “A Better Tomorrow” and “The Killer”, Wong Kar-Wai’s “Fallen Angels” (309301) and “Ashes of Time” (309077), Chen Kaige’s “Farewell My Concubine” (306547) and “The Big Red”, Xie Jin’s “Hibiscus Town”, Ang Lee’s “The Wedding Banquet” (306767) and Hou Hsiao Hsien’s “A City of Sadness”. With photography by Chris Doyle and narration read by Tony Rayns. In English, Cantonese and Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: Typically British: Irish cinema: ourselves alone?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
Typically British. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Francois Truffaut once observed that the words ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ seemed incompatable. In his celebration of 100 years of British Cinema, Stephen Frears shapes an elegant and witty riposte to this statement. In discussion with other British film-makers, Frears explores the wealth of stylish and familiar images created by the British film industry over the last century. “Irish Cinema: Ourselves alone”. Produced and directed by Donald Taylor Black. Narrated by Gabriel Byrne, this documentary looks at the struggle of Irish people to create an Irish cinema. Carefully intercutting interviews with directors, writers and producers with clips from feature films, location footage and fascinating archive material, Donald Taylor Black compares past and present in order to ask questions about the future of Irish cinema.

results.title: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea
results.creator_credit: Jang Sun-Woo, Nagisa Oshima, Eiko Oshima, Park Ki-Yong and British Film Institute
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
‘Nagisa Oshima’s 100 Years of Japanese Cinema’ is a fascinating personal journey through the history of Japanese film-making which moves from the end of the 19th century through to the mid-90s. A rare chance to see stills and excerpts from classic films made in Japan. Oshima comments on his own films as well as the Japanese film industry and its relationship to the country’s political and social changes. Films by great Japanese directors from Muzoguchi, Ozu, Kurosawa, ‘Beat’ Takeshi Kitano, Manga films and Japanese documentary makers are all discussed. ‘The Cinema On The Road’ is a wonderful documentary which uses the road movie genre as a device to explore the history and current contexts of Korean Cinema. With interesting footage of the Korean landscape and cities, as well as interviews with directors and excerpts and stills from films, this is a fascinating insight into a national cinema which is rarely seen. Both documentaries are in English with interviews and film excerpts in Japanese and Korean with English subtitles.
results.title_for_label: The Century of cinema: Japan and Korea

results.title: The Century of cinema. Volume 1 (UK, Ireland, Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Century of cinema”.
White fellas dreaming. Written and directed by George Miller. Produced by George Miller and Doug Mitchell. 1996. Miller presents an entertaining journey through Australian cinema. Cinema is discussed in relation to the changing nature of society and how Australians have constructed and deconstructed a national cinema through celluloid. A must see for anyone interested in Australian cinema heritage. “Cinema of unease. A personal journey by Sam Neill”. Written and directed by Sam Neill and Judy Rymer. Produced by Paula Jalfon and Grant Campbell. 1995. New Zealand cinema is a recent addition to the realm of national cinema, experiencing a significant growth in the previous two decades. Neill visits the land he migrated to and his experience as a performer and a viewer. “Typically British”. Directed by Mike Dibb and Stephen Frears, produced by Colin MacCabe. Frears explores the notion of the incompatibility of ‘British’ and ‘cinema’ in a personal way to present the outstanding films and film-makers of Britain.

results.title: The Circle
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Produced in 1967, this black and white film is an inmate’s view of Daytop, a drug treatment center on Staten Island, New York, where addicts learn to get along without drugs. Uncompromising, often brutal group therapy sessions are designed to shake loose the excuses a victim makes for himself. The people and situations shown are authentic; only one actor was employed. The results obtained at Daytop are regarded by some psychiatrists as a breakthrough. Cast: Don Francks.

results.title: The Christmas tree
results.brief_description: This is a traditional Ukrainian folktale, based on a story by Michaelo Kochubinsky, set in the 19th century. The story concerns eleven year old Ivanko, his parents, a mysterious old man and the “special” Christmas tree that tests the family’s faith and draws them together.

results.title: The Christmas dream
results.creator_credit: B Zeman, K Zeman and Czechoslovak Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A fantasy in which a little girl’s toys come to life in a dream - the toys being played by puppets. (The film is noteworthy for the excellence of the puppet animation in the original material - for American distribution introductory and concluding sequences have been added to the film by Castle Films, USA.). Music only - no language.

results.title: The Champions. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: Donald Brittain, Janet Leissner, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Rene Levesque and Pierre Elliott Trudeau, Canada’s chief political protagonists, are the focus of this two part documentary. Part one covers their early years up to 1967. Using rare photos, newsreel footage and interviews with close political colleagues, the film provides the background to the struggle between the two men and their ideologies. In doing so, it helps to illuminate a great crisis in Canadian history. Awards: Toronto
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Brittain, Janet Leissner, Peter Katadotis and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Chinese connection = Fist of fury
results.creator_credit: Lo Wei, Raymond Chow and National General Pictures
results.brief_description: This martial arts action film stars Bruce Lee as Chen Chen, returning to his former school in early 20th Century Shanghai to learn that his beloved teacher has been murdered. While probing the man’s death and seeking vengeance, Chen discovers that a drug smuggling operation, a rival school, and simmering racial tensions between Chinese and Japanese locals are factors in the nefarious dealings at his school and in his master’s murder. Poorly dubbed into English. Cast includes: Bruce Lee, Robert Baker, Miao Ker Hsiu.

results.title: The Cherry blossom trail
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: Essentially a travel video, “The Cherry blossom trail” uses the revered time of beauty in Japan - Hanami (the brief period of time in which the cherry blossoms, known as sakura, flower before being driven away by the rain - as a compass for this tour of Japan. Beginning in Kyushu, host Greg Grainger and his guide/interpreter Ian visit a shinto shrine, observe the superstitions surrounding Japan’s national flower, visit a canola crop, hot sands and natural springs, countryside walkways, samurai village, origami cranes in the peace park, a traditional tea ceremony, sake and pottery production, geishas, sumo school, traditional villages and a seventeenth century castle, all set against the backdrop of exquisite flowers and gardens. The journey ends at Mount Fuji.

description_for_label: Essentially a travel video, “The Cherry blossom trail” uses the revered time of beauty in Japan - Hanami (the brief period of time in which the cherry blossoms, known as sakura, flower before being driven away by the rain - as a compass for this tour of Japan. Beginning in Kyushu, host Greg Grainger and his guide/interpreter Ian visit a shinto shrine, observe the superstitions surrounding Japan’s national flower, visit a canola crop, hot sands and natural springs, countryside walkways, samurai village, origami cranes in the peace park, a traditional tea ceremony, sake and pottery production, geishas, sumo school, traditional villages and a seventeenth century castle, all set against the backdrop of exquisite flowers and gardens. The journey ends at Mount Fuji.
